body:
I also have this issue. On a system with the following characteristics:

1. Proxy PAC script being used for automated system-wide proxy configuration
1. `Find-Module`,`Invoke-WebRequest` and similar cmdlets work fine on PS v5.1
1. The same cmdlets do not work on v7 GA

---

# Errors

The error is: `Invoke-WebRequest: Response status code does not indicate success: 407 (Proxy Authentication Required).` ... this is the err when `[System.AppContext]::SetSwitch("System.Net.Http.UseSocketsHttpHandler", $false)` has been executed before executing e.g. `Find-Module`

# Debugging

1.

Without executing `[System.AppContext]::SetSwitch("System.Net.Http.UseSocketsHttpHandler", $false)`.

== the error is: `WARNING: Unable to resolve package source 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2'.`

2.

Setting:

```
[system.net.webrequest]::defaultwebproxy = new-object system.net.webproxy('http://IP_OF_PROXY:8080')
[system.net.webrequest]::defaultwebproxy.credentials = [System.Net.CredentialCache]::DefaultNetworkCredentials
[system.net.webrequest]::defaultwebproxy.BypassProxyOnLocal = $true
```
in $PROFILE

== **does not help**.

3. 

Trying to manually authenticate by setting:

```
$WebProxy = New-Object System.Net.WebProxy(“http://IP_OF_PROXY:8080”,$true)
$WebClient = New-Object net.webclient
$WebClient.proxy.Credentials = New-Object System.Net.NetworkCredential($username,$password)
```

== **does not help**

4.
 
Using the `-Proxy` parameter on the cmdlets

== **does not help**

5.

Tried `Unregister-PSRepository -Name PSGallery` >> `Register-PSRepository -Default` 

== **to no avail**

# Various

I've read the issues referred to in this issue posting as well as:

#10460 
#9495 (where @SteveL-MSFT mentions this to be verified working in v7 preview 3 (I'm on v7 GA))
#7827

Same problem as @larssb here.
I tried all the solutions that are mentioned to register the PSGallery repository or using any webcmdlets in our corporate network behind a proxy but nothing helped so far for PowerShell 7.:

**Important**: The **following workaround**, as mentioned from @SteveL-MSFT [here](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/9495#issuecomment-515592672), works with the currently logged in user! **BUT** as soon as I start a Powershell with a different user, it doesn't work with this user anymore (no matter which user i am using). The test users are also member of the local administrator group during tests.

Workaround with current user (NOT working when starting powershell as different user):
```pwsh
[System.AppContext]::SetSwitch("System.Net.Http.UseSocketsHttpHandler", $false)
Invoke-WebRequest https://www.powershellgallery.com
Register-PSRepository -Default -Verbose
```

**WebRequest with different user:** 

```pwsh
[System.AppContext]::SetSwitch("System.Net.Http.UseSocketsHttpHandler", $false)
Invoke-WebRequest https://www.powershellgallery.com

Invoke-WebRequest: Error 12002 calling WINHTTP_CALLBACK_STATUS_REQUEST_ERROR, 'Das Zeitlimit für den Vorgang wurde erreicht.'.
[System.AppContext]::SetSwitch("System.Net.Http.UseSocketsHttpHandler", $false)
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2 -SslProtocol Tls
Invoke-WebRequest: Error 12002 calling WINHTTP_CALLBACK_STATUS_REQUEST_ERROR, 'Das Zeitlimit für den Vorgang wurde erreicht.'.

[System.AppContext]::SetSwitch("System.Net.Http.UseSocketsHttpHandler", $false)
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2 -SslProtocol Tls11
Invoke-WebRequest: Error 12002 calling WINHTTP_CALLBACK_STATUS_REQUEST_ERROR, 'Das Zeitlimit für den Vorgang wurde erreicht.'.

[System.AppContext]::SetSwitch("System.Net.Http.UseSocketsHttpHandler", $false)
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2 -SslProtocol Tls12
Invoke-WebRequest: Error 12002 calling WINHTTP_CALLBACK_STATUS_REQUEST_ERROR, 'Das Zeitlimit für den Vorgang wurde erreicht.'.

Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://40.87.85.101/api/v2 -SslProtocol Tls12 -SkipCertificateCheck
Invoke-WebRequest: Error 12002 calling WINHTTP_CALLBACK_STATUS_REQUEST_ERROR, 'Das Zeitlimit für den Vorgang wurde erreicht.'.
```

**What have I tested?**

```pwsh
$PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

```pwsh
Resolve-DnsName www.powershellgallery.com

Name                           Type   TTL   Section    NameHost
----                           ----   ---   -------    --------
www.powershellgallery.com      CNAME  30    Answer     powershellgallerytrafficmanager.trafficmanager.net
powershellgallerytrafficmanage CNAME  30    Answer     psg-prod-eastus.cloudapp.net
r.trafficmanager.net

Name       : psg-prod-eastus.cloudapp.net
QueryType  : A
TTL        : 10
Section    : Answer
IP4Address : 40.87.85.101
```

```pwsh
[System.AppContext]::SetSwitch("System.Net.Http.UseSocketsHttpHandler", $false)

$DefaultProxy = "http://proxyserver:8080"
$ProxyUri = New-Object System.Uri($DefaultProxy)
[System.Net.WebRequest]::DefaultWebProxy = New-Object System.Net.WebProxy ($ProxyUri, $true)
[System.Net.WebRequest]::DefaultWebProxy.BypassProxyOnLocal = $true
```

OR

```pwsh
[system.net.webrequest]::defaultwebproxy = new-object system.net.webproxy('http://proxyserver:8080')
```

Tried both - with or without setting the credential properties (we are not using any credentials for our proxy)
```pwsh
[System.Net.WebRequest]::DefaultWebProxy

Address               : http://proxyserver:8080/
BypassProxyOnLocal    : True
BypassList            : {}
BypassArrayList       : {}
Credentials           : System.Net.SystemNetworkCredential
UseDefaultCredentials : True
```

or 

```pwsh
[System.Net.WebRequest]::DefaultWebProxy

Address               : http://proxyserver:8080/
BypassProxyOnLocal    : True
BypassList            : {}
BypassArrayList       : {}
Credentials           :
UseDefaultCredentials : False
```

More Details:

```pwsh
$webclient=New-Object System.Net.WebClient
PS C:\Git> $webclient

Encoding                  : System.Text.UTF8Encoding+UTF8EncodingSealed
BaseAddress               :
Credentials               :
UseDefaultCredentials     : False
Headers                   : {}
QueryString               : {}
ResponseHeaders           :
Proxy                     : System.Net.WebProxy
CachePolicy               :
IsBusy                    : False
AllowReadStreamBuffering  : False
AllowWriteStreamBuffering : False
Site                      :
Container                 :


PS C:\Git> $webclient.Proxy

Address               : http://proxyserver:8080/
BypassProxyOnLocal    : True
BypassList            : {}
BypassArrayList       : {}
Credentials           :
UseDefaultCredentials : False
```

Then:
```pwsh
Register-PSRepository -Default -Verbose
VERBOSE: Performing the operation "Register Module Repository." on target "Module Repository 'PSGallery' () in provider 'PowerShellGet'.".
```

Result:
```pwsh
Get-PSRepository -Verbose
WARNING: Unable to find module repositories.
```

I tried setting the proxy configuration through registry in HKLM/HKCU:

```pwsh
'HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings':

ProxyEnable   : 1
ProxyServer   : proxyserver:8080
ProxyOverride : *.local;<local>;test123


'HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings':

ProxyEnable   : 1
ProxyServer   : proxyserver:8080
ProxyOverride : *.local;<local>;test123


'HKCU:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings':

ProxyEnable   : 1
ProxyServer   : proxyserver:8080
ProxyOverride : *.local;<local>;test123
```

I tried setting and using the WinHTTP proxy configuration through netsh

```pwsh
netsh winhttp import proxy source=ie

Aktuelle WinHTTP-Proxyeinstellungen:

    Proxyserver     :  proxyserver:8080
    Umgehungsliste  :  *.local;<local>;test123
```

Also using the `-Proxy` parameter on the cmdlets does not help.

After each change I tried the registration process and the `Invoke-WebRequest` again

EDIT:
After reading [this](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/7827#issuecomment-435798047) from @godeater post, i tried his solution and it is **working** for the webcmdlets but NOT for `Register-PSRepository`!

```pwsh
$env:http_proxy = 'http://proxyserver:8080'
$PSDefaultParameterValues["*:proxy"]=$env:http_proxy
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2

StatusCode        : 200
StatusDescription : OK
Content           : <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><service xml:base="https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2007/app" xmlns:atom="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"><workspace><atom:title ty…
RawContent        : HTTP/1.1 200 OK
                    Cache-Control: no-cache
                    Date: Wed, 15 Apr 2020 10:30:00 GMT
                    Pragma: no-cache
                    Server: Microsoft-IIS/10.0
                    X-CorrelationId: 800034b7-0006-a400-b63f-84710c7967bb
                    DataServiceVersion: …
Headers           : {[Cache-Control, System.String[]], [Date, System.String[]], [Pragma, System.String[]], [Server, System.String[]]…}
Images            : {}
InputFields       : {}
Links             : {}
RawContentLength  : 338
RelationLink      : {}
```

EDIT2: 
Mhm... The `-Proxy` parameter on `Invoke-WebRequest` is also working without setting a `PSDefaultParameterValue` for `-Proxy`, but not with `Register-PSRepository`. So not a step in the right direction after all ;-)

EDIT3:
I can add a second PSRepository but also get the `Unable to resolve package source` error.
After that the Repository exists, but no module can be installed/found or anything else
```pwsh
Register-PSRepository -Name 'PSGallery2' -SourceLocation 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/' -PublishLocation 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/' -ScriptSourceLocation 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/items/psscript/' -ScriptPublishLocation 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/package/' -InstallationPolicy Trusted -PackageManagementProvider NuGet

Get-PSRepository

Name                      InstallationPolicy   SourceLocation
----                      ------------------   --------------
PSGallery2                Trusted              https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/

Find-Module PowershellGet -Repository "PSGallery2"
WARNING: Unable to resolve package source 'https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/'.
Find-Package: C:\program files\powershell\7\Modules\PowerShellGet\PSModule.psm1:8873
Line |
8873 |          PackageManagement\Find-Package @PSBoundParameters | Microsoft …
     |          ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | No match was found for the specified search criteria and module name 'PowershellGet'. Try Get-PSRepository to see all available registered module repositories.
```
Please download and check with latest preview version.

@iSazonov 
thanks for the reply.
I installed the latest preview 1 of 7.1, deleted my powershell profile and rerun the tests (Powershell started as different user).
Same behavior/problems as before. Here is a screenshot:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6794362/79344678-6ea9c900-7f30-11ea-93ba-2e56dd08ea1c.png)

(WinHTTP and SystemProxy is set)

Edit: 

Output from $Error:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6794362/79345730-c5fc6900-7f31-11ea-9c0f-617f5ab44cca.png)

PowershellGet:

```pwsh
Get-Module PowershellGet -ListAvailable


    Directory: C:\program files\powershell\7-preview\Modules

ModuleType Version    PreRelease Name                                PSEdition ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ---------- ----                                --------- ----------------
Script     2.2.3                 PowerShellGet                       Desk      {Find-Command, Find-DSCResource, Find-Module, Find-RoleCapability…}

    Directory: C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules

ModuleType Version    PreRelease Name                                PSEdition ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ---------- ----                                --------- ----------------
Script     2.1.2                 PowerShellGet                       Desk      {Find-Command, Find-DSCResource, Find-Module, Find-RoleCapability…}
Script     1.0.0.1               PowerShellGet                       Desk      {Install-Module, Find-Module, Save-Module, Update-Module…}
```
Thanks! I also #9533. I guess it is .Net Core issue. If you can create simple repo on C# you could open new issue in .Net Runtime (perhaps it already is there).

For me this is unfortunately a show stopper to switch completely to Powershell 7, because in my daily work I very often start the powershell as a different user and therefore have to and want to work as normal as possible. I can install the modules with my standard user account and now have written a script for it but this is of course more than annoying.

It would be great if someone had a solution or at least an info if it is not directly related to Powershell but to .NET Core, PowershellGet or similar.

@eizedev .... maybe [this](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/9495#issuecomment-627839596) could the solution for you. I can't see you mentioning anything about your environment in regards to a proxy. But, give it a look.

This worked for me:

$proxyUri = 'http://proxy.domain.com:8080'
[System.Net.Http.HttpClient]::DefaultProxy = New-Object System.Net.Webproxy($proxyUri, $true)
[System.Net.Http.HttpClient]::DefaultProxy.Credentials = [System.Net.CredentialCache]::DefaultNetworkCredentials

> This worked for me:
> 
> $proxyUri = 'http://proxy.domain.com:8080' [System.Net.Http.HttpClient]::DefaultProxy = New-Object System.Net.Webproxy($proxyUri, $true) [System.Net.Http.HttpClient]::DefaultProxy.Credentials = [System.Net.CredentialCache]::DefaultNetworkCredentials

Setting the proxy for the HttpClient also works for me. You could set the proxy as in  the example above, execute your commands and the unset the proxy for HttpClient this way afterwards:

`[System.Net.Http.HttpClient]::DefaultProxy = New-Object System.Net.WebProxy($null)`
